reviewText:
Sadly, I'm going to have to give this game a thumbs down.  I wanted to recommend it, but the negatives just outwayed the positives here.

The main positive is that it is very cheap to try out.  The main negative is that it becomes very tedious too quickly so that the fun of playing it doesn't last very long.

The game in concept is great; you play a  dinosaur hatched into the cruel, prehistoric, dog-eat-dog world and you must fight your way through hordes of aggressive dinos, beasts, bugs, and plants in order to survive.  This would be a perfectly satisfying theme in the classic hack-and-slash genre, however this is not a classic hack-and-slash game, it is a hack-and-slash-and-clicker hybrid.  And unfortunately the mechanics required to make a game of that genre work well just weren't implemented within this game.

As a clicker you must click every attack as fast as you can to take enemies down before they take you down.  As a hack-and-slasher you are swarmed by many monsters and must manuever yourself optimally on the playing field to tactically dole out damage while also avoiding as much damage as you can.  If you click on a monster you attack it, and if you click on the ground you move to that spot.  It is physically very strenuous, however, to click at the highest rate possible whilst also trying to click on the exact right spot on the screen.  It is made even more difficult when the monsters' hit boxes are clipped exceptionally close to their sprites, the tall bird with the skinny legs I almost always had problems hitting even if I was clicking very close to the leg or neck but not actually upon it. There are item upgrades to improve accuracy ever so slightly, but I found the starting hitboxes especially frustrating.

I also found that my character tended to drift to the top of the screen while playing because as I attacked monsters I seemingly kept clicking the ground behind them if my cursor moved the slightest bit, which would caused my character to move rather than attack.  I think if movement was, perhaps, a key based action and the mouse was solely used for attack, that I would have had more control over my character.

Another rather annyoing aspect of game play is that your character moves very slowly on the playing field itself.  The object of each level is to kill monsters at the fastest rate possible, however you move so slowly around the screen that it interferes with your ability to attack and kill monsters quickly enough to earn the three-star rating of each level.  Also the enemies that have special attacks, like the ground worm which tunnels underneath your character, are almost impossible to avoid unless you happened to already be moving before the incoming attack" indicator appears on the screen.  And while there are stat items to improve mobility
date: there isn't a very good chance that you will acquire one before having to repeat many levels over and over again.\n\nAlso
recommended: you would probably only be able to play this game in short intervals as there is no auto-attack offered with this game either.  Many clicker games have powerups or acquired items which allow for a set dps to be maintained after having played for a while allowing for short rests between frantic clicking
hoursPlayed: but I have not found any such feature available: no friends join you
voteText: no auto-dps skills you can activate on cooldown
helpfulPercent: no items to maintain damage while you aren't clicking.  If you want to play
votesHelpful: you have to be clicking and to keep on clicking (unless you use a third-party auto clicker program
votesFunny: as it defeats the point of playing the game to begin with) until you develope carpal tunnel syndrome.  Each level adds an additional 50 monsters to chew through
commentsCount: and I found even with a freshly rested wrist
column16: that I simply didn't have the stamina to make it through the highest level waves.\n\nWhat else is needed to make a hack-and-slash monster slaughter more satisfing?   Skills and powerup items
column17: of course.  As far as the skills go in the game there are four to unlock and each is associated with a hot-key.   They work well and don't have terrible cooldown times
column18: and it is learning to use these skills at the right time which is crucial for making it through the higher levels.  These four skills enhance the game play well enough and are executed well in the game design.\n\nThe item system
column20: leaves something to be desired.  One acquires items from hatching eggs inbetween levels
column21: and the eggs are obtained by killing monsters during the levels.  Nothing wrong with that
column22: except that there is only a 1 in 5 chance that the egg you break open will have anything inside.  If it does
column23: it is a random item from any of the item categories: weapons
column26: which can boost stats and/or change the look of your character.  Now there is a finite number of items to obtain in the game
column27: and I suppose this system was used so that players could feel like they acquired more items the more they played
column28: but at the same time they wouldn't acquire all the items in the game right away.  The main problem with this is
column29: people don't like the letdown of receiving nothing when they open an egg.  It would have been better to implement some kind of a currency system
column30: like getting gold from the dud eggs
column31: which could be used to purchase the cosmetic items
column32: but also having a 1 in 5 chance of getting a stat item from every egg.  At least then people wouldn't be quite as disappointed after opening 15 eggs in a row that contained no item.\n\nTo sum up
column33: this is kind of an experimental game genre
column36: it is a bad one.  However
column37: all the necessary elements were not there to make this entry an enjoyable game.  With a few tweeks
column38: I would probably change my rating
column40: I rather hope the developers try to make another game of this type but consider what is really needed to make the genre work as a whole."

reviewText:
5.3/10 - A Clicking Marathon!

Pretty spunky Hack N Slash game; take the role of a dinosaur and beat up other dinosaurs and bird-like creatures. It's actually pretty satisfying and keeps your attention until you burn out your wrist!

The whole game revolves around clicking the mouse so gameplay does get old relatively fast, and makes you expend quite a bit of effort. No achievements or trading cards. Only purchase this is you really enjoy this genre.

Worth $1; Look for on sale!
